unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked me about getting started with the stock market, especially as a student in India. My journey started pretty rough, tbh. I remember back in 2018, a friend, let's call him Rohan, convinced me to invest in a penny stock. He said it was a sure thing, "guaranteed returns, bhai!". I put in ₹5000, thinking it was a small amount to risk. Within a week, the stock price plummeted by 80%. That was a hard lesson learned!
normalised: Okay, so someone asked me about getting started with the stock market, especially as a student in India. My journey started pretty rough, to be honest. I remember back in two thousand and eighteen, a friend, let's call him Rohan, convinced me to invest in a penny stock. He said it was a sure thing, "guaranteed returns, bhai!". I put in rupee five thousand, thinking it was a small amount to risk. Within a week, the stock price plummeted by eighty percent. That was a hard lesson learned!

unnormalised: After that initial disaster, I decided to actually learn something before throwing more money away. I started reading articles on Investopedia and followed some reputable analysts on Twitter. I also opened a Demat account with Zerodha – their interface seemed less intimidating. Started small, investing in blue-chip companies like Reliance and TCS. Didn’t put in more than Rs. 2000 at first, just wanted to get a feel for how things moved.

I started reading articles on Investopedia and followed some reputable analysts on T-w-i-t-t-e-r. I also opened a Demat account with Zerodha – their interface seemed less intimidating. Started small, investing in blue-chip companies like Reliance and T-C-S. Didn’t put in more than rupees two thousand at first, just wanted to get a feel for how things moved.

unnormalised: One thing I learned quickly is patience. The market fluctuates, and there are ups and downs. There was a major dip during the COVID crisis in March 2020; Nifty fell below 8000. I was tempted to panic sell, but I remembered reading about Warren Buffet's advice to be greedy when others are fearful. So, instead of selling, I actually bought a few more shares of some fundamentally strong companies.
normalised: One thing I learned quickly is patience. The market fluctuates, and there are ups and downs. There was a major dip during the C-O-V-I-D crisis in March two thousand and twenty; Nifty fell below eight thousand. I was tempted to panic sell, but I remembered reading about Warren Buffet's advice to be greedy when others are fearful. So, instead of selling, I actually bought a few more shares of some fundamentally strong companies.

unnormalised: And now, a few years later, that patience has paid off. Those shares have appreciated significantly, and I’m much more comfortable managing my portfolio. I still only invest what I can afford to lose, and I always do my research before making any decisions. Remember, its not a get rich quick scheme, and you should consult a SEBI registered financial advisor before investing. Good luck, and happy investing!
